div1.p: The author does not believe that Ames was ever officially transferred to the Board. However, he does think that no one could have done the work of caring for the yellow fever patients as well as Ames.

div1.head: Letter fragment to [William M. Brumby], [n.d.]

p.add:
Part of letter to Dr. Brumby that
Gen. Turby referred to in included
letter.
p.del: and I think it a marvelous production.

div1.p:
In regard to S. O. 83, I subscribe thoroly with the contents of the
letters of both Mr. Anderson and Mr. Hirsch, as they put it. But
neither of them subscribe to it in the phraseology you would desire.

They still leave one to decide if Ames was transferred to be a mem-
ber of the Board. They don't say that this order was instigated in
the Surgeon General's Office in Washingtom, where it would have to
come from to make an appointment to thids Board.

Major Reed could have requested the Chief Surgeon in Havana to
transfer Ames to him for duty, but no one in the Department of
Western Cuba would have authority to originate an order appointing
Ames to the Board.

I would think that such an order if it came through military chan-
nel's from Washington at that time would have read something like
this: “Pursuant to instructions from the Surgeon General of the
Army, (date) Washington, D.C., Acting Assisitant Surgeon Roger Post
Ames, etc., etc. and then would have named him as a replacement or
member of the Board. This would have come through the Adjutant
General's office. (which existed at that time).

I think such an important order would have constituted a Special
Order in its own right and not be mixed up with transfers of en-
listed men to the same place and various orders to other persons.

Of course all of the above is just my dim remebbrance of Army
paper work, Gen. and Spec. Orders, etc. I am just a layman and
never held any official position there, so nothing I say is at
all authoritive. But, I regret to say, that I do not believe
that Doctor Ames was ever officially transferred to the Board,
and I am quite certain that no such order will ever be found.
And one cannot take a definite Army Order and translate it into
something we would like to believe, worthy as that belief is.

I guess that Major Reed was not bothering much about a Board at
that time, anyway. The Sanarelli dispute had been settled--Lazear
had solved the mystery of transmission--The only use of of a
Board was to sigh official papers. All Major Reed required then
was an efficient, officer, doctor, yellow fever expert to put in
charge of Camp Lazear and the Fever section. He got that in the
person of Doctor Ames, and no one in all Cuba could have done the
work so well. perhaps he was not a member of the Board, but he
should have been. At that time Carrol and Agramonta might as well
not have been there. The former slowly recovering from Y.F. and
the latter away most of the time with his duties in Havana. Ames
was practically the only man Reed had at that time.

I regret that I cannot be of more assistance to you in the more
favorable way I know you desire, but the foregoing is the only
way I can see it. S. O. 83 is just an order meaning only what it says
on its face and nothing more.
